commentary:
The problem with AI learning is that it's becoming multi-sector: everyone can chip in to learn and apply it to their own sector.

I see this closely in robotics. Computer vision engineers want to test their models on something dynamic and unpredictable. They build a basic robot and test it. They inadvertently learn mechanical design, power systems, embedded systems, etc.

AI needs to learn on physical systems, and the best physical system that encompasses all of this is robotics.

I personally integrate LLMs with swarms of robots, to realize how LLMs may seem logical but they constantly fail in grasping fundamental knowledge. I call this the "Aha" moment—when an AI model observes its real behavior in the real world.

So, ask them to develop AI on constrained systems, and they will with time start to get the real-world application of AI.
